topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521c3c263687241eead1100#post_5521c3c263687241eead1100
Even though you are right about how a lot of people think they're entitled to stereotypical spouses the dude raised a point though; if say 90% of men in the usa stop being sexually interested in women that's going to be a problem in the long run.

Obviously I'm not saying that people are entitled to stereotypical "perfect" spouses, but that in all probability there's two outcomes to this:
A)People stop reproducing like what is happening to japan and how there's entire generations of people that aren't interested in ever having sex.
B)Men will fill that femininity gap.


Call me crazy, but I think both scenarios might happen because look at your average male college student; no girlfriend, no kids and a growing number of them never get either.  While on the surface this sounds good the usa no longer has a stable birth rate and the only reason why we're still growing is due to immigration.  If it wasn't for immigration the usa would be currently up shitter creek without a paddle.
The second scenario can be presented by using japan as a analogy; even though japanese culture vilifies crossdressing, mtf and such otakus are the majority of the younger generations and a lot of otakus in real life prefer traps over born female individuals.


Basically what I'm getting at is that in a purely hypothetical scenario but if we ever reach the point where it's considered socially unacceptable for women to act in a feminine manner I would not be surprised if birth rates in the usa just crash into oblivion instantly.


Tl:dr; if that ever happened:
24/7 news, "Congratulations!  Societally women are no longer allowed to be feminine!"
Next year, "Birth rates have dropped almost completely!"

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521c71563687269c2ac0200#post_5521c71563687269c2ac0200
There are a hell of allot of other things effecting those, Japan also has massive depression issues, depressed people don't want social interactions, it's also massively over crowded, so it's not as worth while to reproduce, to put it simply there is a reason you see slower birth rates in first world countries is a complex set of things, and not as big a deal as it would be in say Nigeria where people die younger and more often, we will likely eventually even out at a new lower population since we just don't need as many people as we used to,

"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521c89163687252a1880700#post_5521c89163687252a1880700
I wouldn't be surprised if it happens eventually cause I know I come off as a sex fiend, but sometimes interesting things are talked about on sex sites cause people are more open about it, the thing is though that more and more men are no longer interested in women.

I'm looking at a five year old study, but since 1970 the percentage of people currently married or in a relationship has been slowly dropping.  How bad has this gotten?  Over 40% of people in the usa that are adults are not in relationships.... That's very fucking bad.

*edit*
Ruh-roh; I found a more recent study by bloomberg magazine; in 2010 only 40% of the usa was single (cnn) and in 2014 it increased to 50% (bloomberg)... uh-oh

"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521c8d66368724418151800#post_5521c8d66368724418151800

topics.author: 509f70a87f123b77eb0004fd

topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521cc546368724bffe72800#post_5521cc546368724bffe72800
Immigration is the only thing keeping the usa afloat at this point, but there's still the relationship problem.  IF people stop en masse reproducing that's going to get ugly and fast.  Even if you offset low birth rates with immigration that still causes severe economic problems because currently one of the biggest things people as a whole spend on is children; if people aren't spending money raising their children then they aren't pumping money into the economy; if they aren't pumping money into the economy well you know.

To use a hyperbole analogy let's say for example people as a whole just decided to stop paying their loan debts; wouldn't that be a problem economically if people just decided to stop using money?
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521ccf963687206aad00200#post_5521ccf963687206aad00200
One thing you are forgetting is there are to many people here, we can't fully mechanize certain jobs because it's still slightly cheaper to use manual labor(look at all the jobs migrant workers do, slowing down progress in those fields by undercutting inovations), as the pool thins it will become more mechanized, Also remember there is a solid chance that the first person to live to 150 years old has already been born, you don't need as many new people when the ones you have can work into the 80-100s

topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521ce8b63687276fb9d0800#post_5521ce8b63687276fb9d0800
The thing is though that we're talking about in the long run dude.

Sure about 70% of the minimum wage workforce is probably going to be mechanized in the next ten years, but the minimum wage workforce is only a small portion of the economy.  It's going to take another 20 to 30 years until the majority of the workforce is mechanized.

In a purely hypothetical scenario to illustrate my point let's say that today people in the usa stopped having sex:
2016: "It's not a problem; there's nothing wrong and we're all okay"
2025: "OH GOD!  THE COUNTRY IS TOTALLED!  THE ECONOMY IS IN RUINS!  REPENT!  REPENT! THE END IS NIGH!"
2035: "Well that was certainly the worst depression in history!"

My point is that for the next twenty years we need people to keep having sex to prevent a unprecedented economic depression.  If people for some reason in the usa stopped having sex and reproducing that would be very bad economically.
"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521cfae6368723166111f00#post_5521cfae6368723166111f00

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5521d2f2636872314f090a00#post_5521d2f2636872314f090a00
Lots of reasons for that.
But the divorce rate is not 50%. Because that is calculated when you factor the marriages in a year with the divorces in the same year: which skews towards divorce because the divorces could have been from any year prior.
